Award.AwardTitle: Learning Trajectories to Support the Growth of Measurement Knowledge: Pre-K through Middle School

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is studying measurement practices from pre-K to Grade 8, as a coordination of the STEM disciplines of mathematics and science. This four-year, mixed methods research project tests, revises and extends learning trajectories (LTs) for children's knowledge of geometric measurement across a ten-year span of human development. Specifically, research teams from Illinois State University and the University at Denver are working with children in urban and suburban schools to (1) validate and extend prior findings from previous NSF-funded research developing measurement learning trajectories with children in pre-K to Grade 5, and (2) generate and extend portions of trajectories for geometric measurement for Grades 6-8.

The project employs a form of microgenetic studies with 24-50 children per grade from pre-K through Grade 5 representing a stratified random sample from a specific set of suburban schools. These studies will test the validity, replicability and generalizability of the LTs for length, area, and volume. The goal will be to validate all components of each learning trajectory, goal, developmental progression, and instruction tasks, as well as revising each LT to reflect the outcomes of the experiments. Analysis of variance measures with pre/post assessments in an experimental/control design will complement the repeated sessions method of microgenetic analysis.

To explore and extend LTs for children in Grade 6-8, the project employs teaching experiments. This design is used to generate and extend portions of trajectories for geometric measurement, and to explore critical aspects of measurement in clinical and classroom contexts. This work is coordinated with the teaching and learning standards issued by the Council of Chief State School Officials/National Governors Association, the National Council of Teachers of Mathematics, the National Science Teachers Association, the American Association of the Advancement of Science, and the National Research Council with cognitive and mathematics/science education literature. Emerging constructs for the hypothetical LT levels in relation to relevant frameworks generated by other researchers and those implied by standards documents to establish ongoing sequences of the experimental interventions for grades 6-8 are being compared, critiqued and evaluated.

This project provides a longitudinal account of pre-K to Grade 8 children's ways of thinking and understanding mathematical and scientific concepts of measurement based upon empirical analysis. The resulting learning trajectory will represent state of the art integrated, interdisciplinary, theoretically- and empirically-based descriptions of increasingly sophisticated and complex levels of thinking in the domain of measurement (albeit, more tentative for Grades 6-8). This account will be used to verify and/or modify existing accounts of children's development of reasoning from short-term analyses of learning or cross-sectional studies. There are not yet integrative longitudinal studies describing this cognitive domain for area or volume measurement. This trajectory-based analysis of development and instruction supports the design and testing of integrative, formative assessment of individuals and groups of children. Such learning trajectories will be useful in implementing the standard-focused curriculum described in the Common Core State Standards Mathematics and in supporting the multiple large assessment projects currently underway.

Project Outcomes Report:

The Children’s Measurement Project

Children follow natural paths as they grow and learn. They learn to crawl, then walk, then run, skip, and jump, with increasing speed and dexterity. As students, they follow similar natural paths in learning mathematics. Curriculum activities and teaching strategies that promote thinking and learning along those paths promote students’ engagement and achievement.  A combination of the learning paths and teaching based on them is called a learning trajectory. Learning trajectories answer the most important questions in education. What goals should we hold for students? Where do we start? How do we know where to go next? How do we get there?

 

Educators know quite a lot about learning trajectories for many topics in mathematics. However, we do not know much about how students think and learn about the topic of measurement: length, area, and volume. This is unfortunate, because measurement is one of the main real-world applications of mathematics. Also, measurement includes and connects two other important topics, geometry and number.

 

In the Children’s Measurement project, we evaluated, developed, and improved learning trajectories for measurement. The goal was to produce clear, complete, and useful descriptions of students’ thinking and learning about measurement and how to best teach it.  We worked with students from preschool through the eighth grade.

 

As an illustration, consider our learning trajectory for area. One of the key developments is for students to understand the structure of regions such as rectangles. That is, many students say “area is length times width” without understanding why that multiplication works. They do not see that the width can be thought of as the “number of rows” in an array of unit squares and the length indicates how many of the squares are in each row. Without that understanding, they do not even understand that it is the unit squares that we are counting to find the area. Therefore they learn the formula by rote, often confusing it with other formulas (e.g., a rectangle’s perimeter equals “2l + 2w”) and failing to apply it creatively when the shape to be addressed is not a rectangle.

 

We conducted two studies to evaluate two different experimental approaches to helping students build these foundational ideas. In one approach, children were taught to iterate units. That is, one might measure the width of a rectangle in inches with a ruler, labeling the dimension including inch units, marking tick marks at each inch along that side, then iterating, or repeating, a single tile along that side while saying, “So that makes 1, 2, 3… rows.” Then one could measure and label the length side, lay out a row of inch tiles along the length while saying, “So that makes 1, 2, 3… in every row.” One would then tape this row of tiles together, iterate it along the first dimension, and use skip counting to determine the area of the whole rectangle.

 

In the second experimental approach, subdividing, one might measure the vertical side of a rectangle by labeling the length of this side, then laying the ruler at each mark and drawing horizontal line segments across the rectangle, thinking “This side is 5 inches so that makes 5 rows.” Similarly measuring and labeling the length of the horizontal side, one would then draw vertical segments across the rectangle at each inch mark. This results in an array of inch squares filling the rectangle. Then, skip counting or multiplication can be used to determine the area meaningfully.

 

Our first study was with students in grades 2 to 5 and then we worked with students from grades 1 to 3 in a second study. In general, we found that both experimental approaches were more effective than traditional teaching of the area formula. Helping students think about units, putting units together (e.g., in “a row”) and structuring two-dimensional space into rows and columns led them to better understanding of area measurement. The subdividing teaching approach—in the form of a drawing of organized rows and columns—helped students see and understand the structure of the two-dimensional array most effectively. Students also learned skills and concepts. We also found that these students performance on the tasks matched the learning paths of our learning trajectory in order, validating that trajectory. We also highlighted an effective way to teach area for students at relevant levels along the trajectory.

 

In summary, the Children’s Measurement project helped establish a better research base to inform curriculum development, professional development, and assessment. We have produced scientific reports and resources for all educators and parents (http://www.childrensmeasurement.org and http://learningtrajectories.org). This is a critical need, given that international studies identify measurement as the area of least relative competence for U.S. students. Given learning trajectories-based instruction, they will learn more effectively and be motivated to do so.
